title: Before 8 January 2022, will Facebook allow Donald Trump to post on Facebook and/or Instagram from any of his verified accounts?
preds: Doesn’t seem to be any reason for Facebook to adjust their position.
Updating it to reflect the impending deadline.
Trump's continuing statements will mean Facebook will not let him back on.
FB is a democrat party asset. So no.
He has gone too far down the road of insanity and encouraging violence

With immense investments in his private social media platform, he may not even ask for it to be reinstated.  His preference to prize his own brand and the ability to put a company on display in opposition to those that kicked him out is too much of a draw for him.

heightened attention on the Jan 6th investigation in Congress with added subpoenas and contempt charges filed against Steve Bannon.  More and more convictions of those who stormed the Capitol in regular media.  Add in Facebook's concerns about public perceptions after recent whistle blower evidence presented to Congress and leaked to the press.  These factors drive down my estimate.

I think if there's a legal battle, it would go well past New Year's Day. Before then, if ever, it seems it's a hard line no. Note: Facebook is now named Meta after lots of controversy surrounding the site.
Not going to happen near to Jan 6 anniversary as it would result in bad PR

Very unlikely. Zuckerberg has enough trouble in his in-box as it is without re-opening that can of worms.  Meanwhile Trump is working towards launching his own TRUTH platform which - if he can get it going - will take the heat off FB / Twitter &c  to let him back on to their sites.

I am revising my forecast up just a bit because with strong results in VA and NJ, there is a small chance (say, 10%) that Trump impulsively declares early for 2024 just to get his name back in the news and try to assert that, as a candidate, he must be let back on Facebook, which they may then oblige (50/50 chance of then doing so within the next 60 days).

slight movement down as time gets closer.  With elections on many issues taking place now (early Nov) and a lot of media coverage discussing Trump (and his supports) pushing for reforms based on debunked claims of election fraud in 2020, the topics that resulted in his suspension are still dominating.  The rhetoric is still high, and Facebook could easily site these continued controversies as evidence that reinstatement is bad for Facebook.

The company announced June 2021 two-year ban drives the percent chance of Trump being reinstated by January 2022 extremely low.  Additionally, dynamics on the political front for Facebook do not support Trump’s reinstatement before the 2022 elections. Lastly, there is a lawsuit against Facebook; however, such suits take one to two years to resolve. I don’t foresee this lawsuit changing Facebook’s June decision to ban him until 2023 before 8 January 2022.

With new pressure on Facebook to moderate content, and with their recent whistleblower scandal. FB could either moderate content more strictly or it could change its algorithms, if it does decided to do something. However, midterm elections may also increase pressure for FB to allow him to use the platform. With this things in mind, I think that FB will not change a lot about its platform and money making/market models, and will wait for the US government to implement regulation. With its track record, it seems to do the least amount of change as possible in order to protect profits. Allowing Trump to use its platforms may lead to profit losses. Therefore, it is not likely that they will allow him access as of now.

While not impossible, given the recent revelations about Facebook's business model and its willingness to allow its algorithm to cause harm to some subscribers (particularly on sister site Instagram), I view it unlikely that Facebook will allow Trump to resume posting from his accounts whether he declares he is running for president again or not.
Not unless they suddenly have a change in leadership, policy, and ethics by 8 Jan 2022.
Just an interesting note … doesn’t change my opinion.  https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2021/oct/02/donald-trump-asks-florida-judge-to-force-twitter-to-reinstate-account
In May the Oversight Board determined that the Trump ban was justified and recommended keeping in place.

With only four months to go and no indication that the status quo will change, Doing so ahead of the Jan 6 Capitol attack anniversary seems a bit like asking for criticism. If anything, recent controversy regarding Facebooks cross check-program, not least vis a vis Trump, might make this less likely. This is my assumption, based on what I believe is an unwillingness to invite further accusations of leniency against disinformation when disseminated by celebrities. (https://techcrunch.com/2021/09/21/the-oversight-board-wants-facebook-to-explain-its-controversial-rules-for-vips/?guccounter=1&guce_referrer=aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZ29vZ2xlLmNvbS8&guce_referrer_sig=AQAAAEZeDqmLpSgCt9GWIeNkrREIqxbzf-po8cpz-oCpKAw_nuZ6SAwhuji6CShVhA2bmksTo9kFrQG9eOoGAuW7Blz1oW7KoIQbdkm0Yjzs0ScGnQas3MoqJjQQGVTI-SND4WR_jrHkod6KaucKe_hV954rbK6uChq1z1uQOfVBFive)

4 months until then
No indication that FB is relenting on blockin
Will not happen close to 8 JAN due to the anniversary of 6 JAN
I don't see this changing from the status quo

First, will Donald Trump even ask to be reinstated?  He may balk at that in favor of citing unfair treatment as a deflection being declined.  He also seems to have found ways to get out his message on other platforms.  If he does ask, the date of 8 Jan is too close to the 6 Jan insurrection attempt at the US Capitol for facebook/Instagram to agree.  In fact, as September ends and November is around the corner, there are too many opportunities for Facebook/Instagram to say "it's only been a year" and there have been limited times where Donald Trump has demonstrated a change in his social media presence/tactics.

FB would rather take the easy way out and keep his posts from creating potential liability for them at least until after 2022, when Trump would consider another campaign for POTUS. They also want to not so badly tick off the Dem-trifecta in Congress who are weighing tighter regulations against social media platforms.  My only point of hesitation is that Trump may choose to run for the House of Reps - in some (un)spoken scheme to get himself elected Speaker of the House - within the next few months - changing the facts on the ground that factor into allowing him to reach the public.

I see there's some interest in the idea he'll return before 8th Jan.  I can't see replatforming DJT just before insurrection day as a good idea, it's likely to bring FB back into the picture as a regulatory target.   Couple this with the fact the Oversight Board is a way for FB to avoid government regulation and interference, I find it very unlikely there will be any changes made to this position, without going through a Board review first.  Then, even if this was to happen, I doubt the Board will overturn it's previous decision, or suggest that it is appropriate for FB to adjust any ban durations ad hoc, without thorough review.

Facebook claims that the ban will last until 2023: https://www.npr.org/2021/06/04/1003284948/trump-suspended-from-facebook-for-2-years They do include a clause that they can un-ban him "if the risk to public safety has receded" but honestly I think they'd rather just keep him off the platform and wash their hands of it. Letting him back on would likely cause a mild uproar, and then there's a non-negligible chance they'd have to re-ban him which would cause yet another uproar. Now that they're committed, I think it's in their favor to just stay the course.
No chance. Trump is unlikely to grow and change by then.
From the reports that I have read truth and reality remain foreign to the Donald.
I think Facebook is happy to free itself of Trump-related controversy from a PR perspective, especially considering the political scrutiny they have been under.
Facebook is trying to please regulators - unlikely during Biden administration

Zuckerberg is a weasel so anything is possible. But Trump is unlikely to stop lying and Facebook will continue to face regulatory pressure from the Biden administration, and allowing Trump back on the platform probably won't help him deal with regulatory scrutiny.

FB moderators are poorly trained, lack any authority, and are prevented from doing their jobs by managers who are also poorly trained and lack any real authority. FB's policies are not enforced uniformly or consistently.  FB has very serious issues that are not being addressed by upper-management.  The lack of leadership at FB is shocking at best.  Allowing Trump back would only demonstrate FB's many problems and create additional problems that would not be handled in a professional manner!
There seems to be no pressure for a move in this direction.  Thus no upside for Facebook to reinstate him.
Allow? Yes. Will he post? Likely not
Facebook reviewed the rules and said they would uphold his suspension for at least 2 years.

FB has announced he's banned. https://about.fb.com/news/2021/06/facebook-response-to-oversight-board-recommendations-trump/
The question now is whether FB reverts the decision. What could cause a reversion? 
- Internally, Facebook could decide they were too harsh and make some sweeping changes to its policy that affects the trump ban (@Barnstable made this point). I don't think it's likely they'll deal with trump directly and individually.
- Externally, political and social pressure could do it. I don't currently know of any signals that are indicative to change, but we have another 7 months until this closes. Things may change until then. Putting all this together, I think there is some chance, but i'm highly doubtful it will revert.
No appetite to add Trump back to mainstream social media.  He's slowly becoming irrelevant.

I'm posting this after the 2-year ban. I believe there still exists a decent chance that the growing revelations about how inconsequential the Jan. 6 incident really was, how little Trump's rhetoric actually affected events (timeline issues), and a universally increasing disgust with Zuckerberg's star chamber censorship tactics could result in enough consumer pressure to reinstate a number of banned accounts. This would not likely be centered on Trump; rather, a sweeping rules change would affect Trump's ban along with a swath of others.
Wow yes, looks to be banned for the next two years: https://www.economist.com/the-world-this-week/2021/06/12/business-this-week?fsrc=scn%2Ftw%2Fte%2Frfd%2Fpe
I underestimated the FB censorship and how the left view any opinions different from the left as criminal.

Official blog post announcement is here, and they won't allow him back on until after the 2022 elections, at which point they will re-assess: https://about.fb.com/news/2021/06/facebook-response-to-oversight-board-recommendations-trump/
I think will be a pressure over Facebook leaded by conservatims social forces
After a long losing streak, it's nice to actually have gotten something right. GG all

Still wild cards at play. A judicial order to reinstate, conditions warranting a return, lots of time left. Though best bet is this resolves NO. The crowd's hunch was right… this time around. https://about.fb.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/Facebook-Responses-to-Oversight-Board-Recommendations-in-Trump-Case.pdf
Even if review board comes back, the odds this leads to a post in 2021 looks decidedly low
I was wrong on this one, -59, leaving a 1% chance they change their mind.

What a great day for public mental sanity. He will probably re-emerge with another blog, called "Talk from the Trump Tower Elevator" or "Notes from the Trump Resort golf course" or "Philosophic abstracts from the Trump Winery tasting room" or "Desperations of the NYC Trump legal team" or "The long odyssey of a former U.S. president to finally receive appropriate mental health care and aggression therapy" or simply "The official Donald J Trump Junk Bin".
Wow they came quick with that decision. Some small chance the review board comes back

FB just announced that it will bar him for 2 whole years.   https://thehill.com/policy/technology/556884-facebook-suspending-trump-until-at-least-2023 I need to read the fine print.  Is there a loophole and he can get back on Instagram????

Highly unlikely. It would only be the result of pressure from the US Government and it's simply not a priority of the Biden Administration or anyone else. The only resulting pressure that could emerge would be from Fox news and they haven't taken much interest so I would be shocked if there's much else to the story. I would imagine some posts on behalf of Trump from other networks (his family, organizational pages) should he kickstart a 2024 campaign but I cannot see the official pages being used in the near future.

So I’ve been reading Think again by Adam Grant and I took the time to read other point of views.
And in doing so I’ve come to a thinking that it’s all about $ and he will be aloud back on for one reason, the traffic it will bring to the platform and the entertainment that he will provide to the platforms out ways the negative effects he has on the platform.

The former guy is now telling people he could "reinstated," with a Myanmar-style military coup coming soon:
https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-expects-to-be-reinstated-as-president-august-2021-6 Facebook and Instagram aren't letting this guy back on, no way

So Facebook has 6 months from May to take action according to the oversight board decision. A very good analysis of the oversight board decision can be found here: https://podcasts.apple.com/cr/podcast/bonus-understanding-facebook-oversight-board-decision/id1460055316?i=1000520470444&l=en The basic thing is that they said that FB was reasonable in taking down the content of DJT's posts at the time, but that overall the ban on DJT himself was "Standardless": "Given the seriousness of the violations and the ongoing risk of violence, Facebook was justified in suspending Mr. Trump’s accounts on January 6 and extending that suspension on January 7. However, it was not appropriate for Facebook to impose an ‘indefinite’ suspension." So that all looks good for DJT to return, especially since it will be hard to argue (or at least hard to prove) the harm is as clear and present as, say, on Jan 6th. And if he were not still harping about the election, I think it's super high likelihood he's back on. So the question is going to be how hard they hold him to account for the fact that he isn't dropping the claims, and if they can spell out that logic in a rule that is generally applicable. That's a tall order. So very roughly I see these outcomes: 65% chance he's back on; 10% chance penalty extended explicitly; 25% chance facebook does a tweak and sort of punts it back to oversight board.  https://oversightboard.com/news/226612455899839-oversight-board-upholds-former-president-trump-s-suspension-finds-facebook-failed-to-impose-proper-penalty/

The GOP civil war between the populist arm and the business arm is unlikely to encourage Facebook to rescind the ban. The increasing prevalence of denial in the populist arm represents an unwarranted risk of liability.
My independent probabilistic forecast would be similar to that of @Anneinak's 70% as of 29 May. But unfortunately (maybe fortunately, we'll see) I am torn because of other arguments.

I think that DJT's rhetoric at rallies will have a major influence on the decision by Zuckerberg, et. al.   DJT loves crowds; they pump him up.  I do not see DJT changing his style or cooling down his rhetoric.  All reports are that he is still grousing about how the election was stolen, etc.
Has any celebrity banned by Facebook ever come back onto the site? For example, Alex Jones? https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/far-personality-alex-jones-banned-015412444.html

Down because of @MCowley's great judgement. However, I'm stubborn because of my prior about Facebook's historical tolerance and reluctance to censor Trump's accounts. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1282860

Dropping my forecast after some overdue review, mainly due to timeline.  Facebook (FB) has shown no interest in fully committing to banning DJT from their platforms, I can only assume this is a combination of his following and a complete ban of DJT will be perceived as proof of the alleged bias against Conservative views. At the start of May the oversight board delivered deadline of 6 months for FB to make a decision, which included placing a timeline on his return to their platforms (1). Given the tightrope FB is walking attempting to keep their users engaged, I'm anticipating FB to not announce their decision until the 11th hour (or month in this case), and believe there's a high chance that an additional 3 - 6 month ban to be announced to allow his return AFTER the Jan 6th milestone.  I'm inclined to keep tabs on their user totals (2), if this shows any sign of decline, returning DJT to either platform will likely generate more traffic than it loses. 1. https://www.npr.org/2021/05/05/987679590/facebook-justified-in-banning-donald-trump-social-medias-oversight-board-rules
2. https://www.statista.com/statistics/264810/number-of-monthly-active-facebook-users-worldwide/

Just saw the Open Secrets page on where Facebook employee contributions went: https://www.opensecrets.org/orgs/facebook-inc/totals?id=D000033563
The crowd average of 25% remains too high. Why would Facebook employees want this guy back? I also don't know that there's an indication the guy even wants to come back to that site or Instagram.

Okay, raising a little. in response to crowd. But I still think as long as he keeps putting out statements like the 2020 Election was "Rigged and Stolen" and "the Crime of the Century," I can't see how Facebook wants to touch that with a 10-foot pole.
Facebook only cares about money and trump is sirely a money spinner for them. As time passes he will be seem as less dangerous and will undoubtedly be allowed back into Facebook.

Scandals, future rallies, and inspired sympathizers can't be ruled out that will swing this the other way. I am not very confident because of the timing and confusion between what certain things mean. I lean toward yes, though.

The oversight board seem to think that the case was based upon the balance between voice and safety, and it seems re-establishing his voice while blocking new posts on a case-by-case basis would embody those principles without facebook alienating a big republican tribe-- maybe half of their profitable USA users
https://oversightboard.com/decision/FB-691QAMHJ/
The situation in six months will be less urgent than five months ago.

Drop a couple pp because his org is under criminal investigation now*. If he gets incarcerated, I could see less of an incentive to maintain social media on both sides. However, maybe to Trump this will encourage him to join social media. But then again, there is the risk of him causing a social media rally before being handcuffed away which will freak the moderating teams on the social media platforms and encourage them to maintain birth control. Nonetheless, this scenario is still a low probability event. In summary, I still think likely but my conviction is not as strong. *https://thehill.com/homenews/state-watch/554252-new-york-prosecutors-investigating-trump-organization-in-a-criminal
The position to ban an extremely popular former POTUS is untenable.

FB will decide in 6 months.
It's Christmas season in 6 months, and the past tensions are relieved.
Decision to uphold the ban will be essentially a "new ban" decision. Harder to make than just not renewing the old ban, and consistent with the board's recommendation of "past bans being time-limited, and this one should be no different from other similar cases"

Facebook plays to its crowd, and one can speculate that the general population of users either actively dislikes the Trump factions, or doesn't care. Facebook also filters most decisions through the ramifications and effects on its advertising models, and in a non-election cycle, Trump's presence would not seem to provide a great benefit. Finally excluding Trump virtue signals to regulators that Facebook seems to care about eliminating disinformation
Facebook will ban Trump for at least a full year

My impression is that FB will make a decision in the 6 month timeframe (80%) rather than delaying. Why would they undercut their independent oversight board on their first important decision? But, I am less sure about the ultimate result (50-50?).
Former president and no current risk of violence. New Facebook policy of conditionally allowed but will be permanent ban if repeats .

They are not in any hurry to decide this.  They'll use every second of the six months to conduct their "review," then they'll take a couple of months to draft new rules, then allow a couple more months for comments, then take a month or so to revise the proposed new ones.  Whatever they finally come up with, it will almost certainly slop over into '22.
Facebook seems indifferent about the issue; more likely to keep the status quo than not.

First reason : Urgency
Donald Trump had lost the election. He has no significant position in the government right now. The urgency is very low to revoke the banned.
Second reason : controversy
we know that social media like Facebook and Instagram had gotten many pressures about Trump. Donald Trump is controversial even though he's right now not a president of United States anymore. Those platform would like to maintain status quo and for this reason they will be playing safe. I mean it's safer for them to not lift the banned. 
Third reason : political bias
We all know that all the platforms don't mention their political affiliation, and they are pursuing their best effort to be neutral. How do we know Facebook's employees don't side certain politician? We don't know. But they banned of Donald Trump, the president of United states is a strong evident that they have some bias towards Donald Trump. If we'd like to be honest, how many politicians lie and not get banned? They certain have bias towards Trump.

Why this could resolve as "Yes" The one thing that Zuckerberg has been paranoid about is having an unchallenged supremacy over social media platforms. He owns the largest 2 (FB and Instagram) and the largest messaging service (whatsapp). FB has 2bn monthly active users and Insta has about 1 bn. If Zuckerberg were to indefinitely extend this ban there could be some repurcussions, infact there`s already talk of a platform for conservatives.
https://www.wsj.com/articles/trump-considers-contenders-to-be-his-new-social-media-outlet-after-big-tech-crackdown-11621013567
Trump does have a large following as was seen by the initial response to the blocking of his social media accounts. 
from the above article
Another right-wing social-media platform, Parler, built a big following after the 2020 election, briefly becoming the most downloaded app in the country and racking up more than 15 million users. The Trump Organization held talks with Parler last year about potentially taking a stake in the company, according to people familiar with the matter. BuzzFeed was the first to report the talks.
The main reason that platforms such as Twitter & FB gave a wide berth to people like DJT is that they were good for business.
https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/01/16/how-twitter-banned-trump/
Excerpt from the above article - 
Public figures were so important to Twitter that, like Facebook, the company long gave them a newsworthiness exemption. They were allowed to say things that would be considered to be policy violations if uttered by everyday users, on the grounds that what these people said was in the public interest. Twitter, and Dorsey in particular, long maintained that even the worst lies should be corrected with more speech rather than removing them. It was Twitter’s responsibility to show “how global leaders think and treat the people around them,” he said. I just think a separate platform for conservatives could be perceived as a threat, which will force Zuckerberg to act and clarify his position rather that drag this indefinite ban for too long.
From DJT`s perspective it makes good sense to try and get on a social media platform as soon as possible rather than waiting for a year, else his supporters may lose their momentum/interest
Not if Biden is still President.

This is a wake up call to tech companies 
https://www.marketwatch.com/story/google-slapped-with-120-million-fine-by-italys-antitrust-watchdog-11620906115

The board’s decision was that Facebook needed to write clear rules, indefinite suspension is too arbitrary. Name the infraction, set the penalty, impose the penalty.  The response to this question appears to be whether the named suspension will be longer than one year.  The wording of the board response leaves it up to Facebook to determine if the ban should be for a limited time or permanent. It also calls for them to apply this standard going forward if rules are broken in the same way.  So Facebook could make the ban permanent OR set a limit, then reimpose the limited penalty if the rule is broken again. They could also create a rule that states after X number of suspensions, the restriction is permanent. Given this option, of monitoring and suspending until a certain number is met, I believe there is a 50/50 chance Facebook will choose to go this route, and a 50% chance they will make it permanent.

Money, not ethics, seem to me to be the predominant motivator for FB's actions. Principled reaction to DJT's posts would have been possible sooner in the years prior. As long as this ban does not adversely affect FB's financial bottom line, I expect them to uphold it. With a reported Q1 yoy +28%.
https://s22.q4cdn.com/826641620/files/doc_financials/2021/q1/Q1'21-Selected-Metrics-and-Financials.pdf
the relevant incentive seems to currently be small.
I expect this to change in case of public perception of establishment of other virtual congregative places for MAGA, as FB will want to not loose that part of US consumers in fear of loosing business.

Reasons why this might resolve as "Yes"
-Zuckerberg seems to not want to censor anyone so might lift the restriction
-this is an "or"/union question.  The solution set of union questions is always larger than that for intersection questions.  FB may continue to deny access while Instagram allows it, for example.
-if the "Big Lie" continues to be widely believed, this may make DJTs posts seem "mainstream" and unoffensive
-it seems conceivable to me that the rules could be written so that DJT could post but only about certain topics:  i.e. limited access 
-DJT might be given conditional  access
-DJT might be given temporary access:  sort of a trial period
-if DJT threatens or is taking all of his followers to another platform, FB & Instagram may relent for business reasons Reasons why this might resolve as "No"
-Zuckerberg punts and let's his prior ruling stand
-a decision is made to bar all current & former state or national elected officials (or something like that).
-DJT dies or has a stroke and is rendered speechless

I have a hard time seeing how Facebook could justify a permanent ban. Particularly when it's a former president. The company itself probably leans left, but it's also incentived to attract users, including conservative ones. As the board notes, Facebook doesn't have clear and consistent criteria, and if they develop criteria over the coming months I doubt it will be criteria that would mean they have to permanently ban every user with a large following who violates Facebook's policies in a way similar to what Trump did. This quote from the board's decision is also worth noting I think: "Facebook should publicly explain the rules that it uses when it imposes account-level sanctions against influential users. These rules should ensure that when Facebook imposes a time-limited suspension on the account of an influential user to reduce the risk of significant harm, it will assess whether the risk has receded before the suspension ends. If Facebook identifies that the user poses a serious risk of inciting imminent violence, discrimination or other lawless action at that time, another time-bound suspension should be imposed when such measures are necessary to protect public safety and proportionate to the risk." I suspect that Trump using the platform will no longer be deemed an imminent risk of increased violence and he'll be allowed back on. Leaving lots of uncertainty though because it's a decision made by a private board with opaque processes that likely is biased to the left.
Trump has not rescinded his "big lie" claims, so I would expect the path of least resistance for Facebook is to simply maintain the status quo
